instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the yield predictions in the research on machine learning-based yield predictions in agriculture, and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the yield predictions in the research was the mean absolute error (MAE). The MAE measures the average magnitude of the errors in the predictions, indicating how close the predicted values are to the actual measured values. In this study, the MAE values ranged from 0.32 to 0.68 Mg/ha, depending on the timing of the predictions. instruction: Can the use of spectral reflectance measurements in machine learning-based yield predictions be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately estimating preharvest yields up to 2 months before harvest?
Output: Yes, the use of spectral reflectance measurements in machine learning-based yield predictions can be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately estimating preharvest yields up to 2 months before harvest. The related study tested the accuracy of machine learning-based yield predictions using spectral reflectance measurements, precipitation, and reference evapotranspiration. The results showed that the best machine learning model had a mean absolute error (MAE) of 0.38 Mg/ha when making predictions on June 30, more than 1 month before harvest. This indicates that the machine learning model was able to accurately estimate the yield with a relatively small margin of error. Additionally, the yield estimations were robust even in the presence of considerable soil variation within the experimental area. Therefore, the use of spectral reflectance measurements in machine learning-based yield predictions can be considered superior to traditional methods for accurately estimating preharvest yields up to 2 months before harvest.
